prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my 3yo out to do something fun whilst my partner is at work?
I will try and keep this short . 

Almost every weekend when I say lets take our kid out to the play centre or a farm ect I get one of maybe 3  excuses every time without fail . Either "I dont want to go out / I just wanna sit and play on the computer. " " ive been at work im tired I don't wanna go out / drive " or " I don't wanna spend the money on x, y ,z" ( we have money so its not like thats a real problem )   

Today a friend asked me if i wanted to go with her with the kids to the farm near us tomorrow and I said yes . I figured since we hadn't taken little one anywhere fun for a few weeks it would be nice . 

So I mentioned it to my partner and he goes off on one about how its not fair as he is at work and he would like to go blah blah . I said so I cant take her anywhere when you're at work ? Pointed out that I asked to go not a week or two earlier and was told no its too expencive and  I dont want to go out I'm tired. ( its £7 each ). 

So now he wants me to cancle with my friend so he can go another day . I said we can go whenever you want . But apparently thats not an option either . 

Its a childrens petting zoo ffs its not like im going to see a movie wothout him. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person (the author) is in the wrong for taking their 3-year-old out to a fun activity while their partner is at work. The situation seems a bit complex.

First, the author mentions that they often suggest going out to places like the play centre or a farm on weekends. Each time, the partner gives excuses like not wanting to go out, being tired from work, not wanting to spend money (even though they have money). The author then decided to take the kid to the farm with a friend because it's been a few weeks since they did something fun. When they told the partner, the partner got upset, saying it's unfair because he's at work and would like to go. The author points out that they had asked before and were denied, and now the partner wants them to cancel the plans so he can go another day. The author is frustrated because it's a kids' petting zoo, not a movie or something else.

Hmm. The key points here are about shared responsibilities, mutual consideration, and the fairness of the situation. The partner is working, and the author is taking the child. On the one hand, the partner might feel left out or that the author is making decisions without considering his feelings. On the other hand, the author is trying to do something for the child when the partner is unavailable and has been resistant in the past. 

The partner's reaction seems a bit over the top because it's a children's activity. If the author already had the commitment from the friend and the partner was at work, maybe the author isn't wrong for going. The partner's previous refusals might mean that the author is acting within their right to plan something when the partner isn't available. Also, the cost is minimal, so money isn't a real issue. The partner's insistence on canceling to go another day might be more about feeling left out rather than a valid reason. 

But maybe the partner feels that the author should have discussed it more, or that they should wait until both can attend. However, the author has been trying for weeks with no success, and the partner is the one who gave excuses before. The author's action is proactive in providing the child with an enjoyable experience. 

So, considering all this, the author isn't in the wrong. They're making a reasonable decision based on the partner's past behavior and the child's need for fun activities. The partner's reaction seems more about their own feelings than a justifiable reason to cancel the plans. Therefore, the answer should be B (No, the author is not in the wrong).
